title: REAL ESTATE CIVIL LAW Is lender TRUST DEED HOLDER suppose to keep records of how payments applied to loan ?
question: Calif bare land loan I was been making payment on a balloon loan that was due in 2005 i kept making payments to pay the loan off as the lender never demanded the balloon payment and said payment were going to payoff loan paid for 9 years at 400 a month they never sent statements of interest or late payments they now want to foreclose by default They have never made demand for balloon payment the loan was 40000 they now want 58000 where do i have paid them over 100000 on this loan since 1993 the foreclosure company is run by a realtor and they refuse to talk and i want to file to stop them in court and I have asked for copies of how the payments How the payment were applied and copies of loan documents and any correspondence they have not given anything no records of payment history BUT THEY HAVE FILED FOR DEFAULT 2 times NOW OVER 3 YEARS AFTER LAST PAYMENT MADE HAVE NOT BEEN ABLE TO FIND LAWYER TO HELP RUNNING OUT OF TIME !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
answers:
No matter what direction you take, you are going to have to litigate the accounting on this loan and have a court make that decision. The terms of the Note will control, along with California Real Property law.
I suggest first consulting with an attorney that handles mortgage litigation. Again, no matter what, I expect that this will be an expensive process. In some instances, a state court will stay (stop) the foreclosure to determine what the balance owed is. You will then have to pay it in a lump sum, since the loan is due.
Just as a supposition and without knowing anything whatsoever about your loan, what if there was a $1,000 per month late penalty, plus interes, since the loan came due? If you paid $400 per month, $600 a month plus unpaid interest would have accrued for many years. The loan balance of $58,000 could easily be correct.

Another option is to file a case under chapter 13, but for non-residential property, the court may not allow you to pay the balance over time. You would still have to litigate that balance, again at a high cost. Paying this off over the maximum 60 months would still be $1,000 per month. The creditor might also be entitled to interest.

Go talk to a real estate litigation attorney and find out if they can help and what the cost would be. Then you have to decide whether that is a less costly option than just getting a loan and paying off the demand of the creditor.
